Title.evidence: Title: Randomised Controlled Trial of Bupivacaine Implants for Postoperative Pain in Abdominoplasty

Trial_Design.evidence: In this multicenter, double-blind, placebo-controlled trial, 366 patients undergoing abdominoplasty were randomised 1:1

Participants.evidence: Eligibility criteria included adults aged 18-65 years with a BMI of 18-35 kg/m².

Intervention.evidence: randomised 1:1 to receive either three 100 mg bupivacaine implants or placebo collagen implants.

Objective.evidence: This study assessed the efficacy and safety of bupivacaine implants (INL-001) versus placebo for managing postoperative pain in abdominoplasty.

Method_Outcome.evidence: the primary outcome was the sum of pain intensity (SPI24) over 24 hours post-treatment.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was stratified by study center and BMI, with allocation concealed using a centralized electronic system.

Blinding.evidence: Patients, clinicians, and outcome assessors were blinded.

Number_Analysed.evidence: A total of 181 patients received INL-001 and 184 received placebo.

Result_Outcome.evidence: The mean SPI24 was significantly lower in the INL-001 group (102, SD 42) compared to placebo (117, SD 45; p=0.002).

Harms.evidence: Adverse events were reported in 84% of INL-001 patients and 87% of placebo patients
